projects.title: Groundbreak
projects.description: What if the arena itself were your arsenal? Groundbreak is a roguelike tactics RPG where you sling element-infused tiles to create reactions; sandstorms, smoke, fireballs and more will help you outsmart a multi-floor dungeon of creepy-crawlies. On a four person team, I led combat design and implementation: tile-flinging, the elemental reaction system, and enemy AI powered by A* pathfinding. My favorite part was iterating with 10+ playtesters, tuning each element so multiple viable build paths emerged, keeping every choice fun. (RIP Sandstorm)

projects.title: Keystone
projects.description: What if NPCs were the puzzle pieces? Keystone is an open-world adventure where NPC behaviors intertwine. By herding, distracting, trading aggro, and luring enemies, players uncover hidden paths and secrets woven into the world’s ecosystem. Working in a four-person cross-fuctional team, I designed six different dungeons built around player-enemy interaction. This was my first experience prototyping and playtesting, creating a lightweight choose-your-own-adventure protoype to help test puzzle flow and ecosystem designs early in development.

projects.title: Fakeflix
projects.description: FakeFlix was my first real dive into front-end development. I expanded a 35k+ React/Redux codebase to add a “Because You Watched” recommendations rail and build new reusable UI components. It was a crash course in how React and Redux intertwine to handle complex states and the satisfaction that comes with making interfaces feel as good as they look. I also dipped my toes in DevOps work for the first time, setting up GitHub Actions to automate testing and keep the codebase stable.

projects.title: Personal Website
projects.description: You’re on it! Designed in Figma and built with Next.js and Tailwind CSS, it began as a way to challenge myself in front-end development. A passion project inspired by League of Legends’ champion pages, I wanted to create a site that where every element not only looks good but feels good, no matter what device you're viewing it from. Now, it serves as my hub for showcasing projects, growth, and the things I love the most.
